content.title: Mechanical Ventilation Modes
content.summary: Mechanical ventilation modes describe how the ventilator delivers breaths. Key categories include volume-controlled (VC), pressure-controlled (PC), and pressure support (PS) ventilation. Modern modes include SIMV, PRVC, and APRV. Mode selection depends on clinical situation, oxygenation/ventilation goals, and patient comfort.
key_points: Volume Control (VC): Set TV, variable pressure; guaranteed volume but risk of high pressures
Pressure Control (PC): Set pressure, variable TV; pressure-limited but variable volumes
Pressure Support (PS): Patient-triggered, pressure-assisted; for weaning and spontaneous breathing
SIMV: Synchronizes mandatory breaths with patient effort; used for weaning
AC (Assist-Control): Full support for each breath; most common initial mode
PRVC: Pressure-regulated volume control; hybrid targeting volume with pressure delivery
content.statement: Mechanical ventilation mode selection should match clinical goals: full support (AC) for critically ill, weaning modes (PS, SIMV) as patients improve, and lung-protective settings (low TV, appropriate PEEP) regardless of mode.

explanation.intuition: Think of modes as different driving modes in a car: Volume Control is like cruise control for distance (guaranteed mileage/TV), Pressure Control is like limiting speed (guaranteed not too fast/high pressure), and Pressure Support is like power steering (helps the patient do the driving).
explanation.key_insight: The most important thing is not which mode you use, but how you set it. Lung-protective settings (6 mL/kg IBW, Pplat ≤30) are critical regardless of mode. Most patients can be managed with AC-VC or AC-PC.
explanation.technical_details: In VC, flow pattern determines how volume is delivered (square vs decelerating). In PC, inspiratory time determines delivered volume. PEEP and FiO2 affect oxygenation; RR and TV affect ventilation (CO2 clearance). I:E ratio affects air trapping.

definitions_glossary.volume_control: Mode guaranteeing set tidal volume with variable peak pressures
definitions_glossary.pressure_control: Mode delivering set inspiratory pressure with variable tidal volume
definitions_glossary.pressure_support: Patient-triggered mode with pressure assistance to each spontaneous breath
definitions_glossary.SIMV: Synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation; mandatory breaths sync with patient effort
definitions_glossary.assist_control: Mode where ventilator supports every breath (mandatory or triggered)
definitions_glossary.PEEP: Positive end-expiratory pressure; prevents alveolar collapse
definitions_glossary.tidal_volume: Volume of gas delivered per breath
definitions_glossary.I_E_ratio: Ratio of inspiratory to expiratory time
definitions_glossary.plateau_pressure: Pressure during inspiratory pause; reflects alveolar pressure
definitions_glossary.PRVC: Pressure-regulated volume control; targets volume using pressure

pathophysiology.mechanism: Mechanical ventilation provides positive pressure to inflate lungs, supporting oxygenation and ventilation

AC_VC.description: Assist-Control Volume Control; most common starting mode
AC_VC.settings: TV 6-8 mL/kg IBW, RR 12-16, PEEP 5+, FiO2 titrate to SpO2 ≥92%

AC_PC.settings: PIP to achieve TV 6-8 mL/kg, RR 12-16, PEEP 5+, FiO2 titrate
AC_PC.disadvantages: Variable TV with lung compliance changes

pressure_support.description: Patient triggers all breaths with pressure assistance
pressure_support.disadvantages: No guaranteed RR; requires intact respiratory drive

definition.@value: Classification and application of different mechanical ventilation modes including volume control, pressure control, and pressure support

learning_objectives: Compare volume control and pressure control ventilation
Select appropriate mode for clinical scenario
Set initial ventilator parameters using lung-protective settings
Recognize when to transition between modes
clinical_pearls: Mode matters less than settings - use low TV regardless of mode
AC provides full support for sick patients; PS for weaning
High peak pressure with normal plateau = airway resistance (bronchospasm, tube kink)
High peak AND plateau pressure = poor compliance (ARDS, pneumothorax)

sources.source: UpToDate. Overview of initiating invasive mechanical ventilation in adults. 2024.
